Bottle. Lovely fruity, hoppy aroma. Dark gold with floaties murking up the gold body. Nice lace. Moderate sized white head. Sweet, almost cloyingly so. very lightly carbonated. Not really enjoying this. Hops are completely subdued by the sugars, which have a citrus aftertaste Im not digging. Not a recipe Lagunitas needs to revisit.
From a bottle poured a copper color with a fair amount of head.  Nice bitter hoppy flavor with a lasting aftertaste.
The only way I can explain this beer is a IPA mixed with holiday spices that is blended to perfection
Pours an attractive deep copper with a cream colored head. Nose and flavor are full and hop forward with pine and citrus, balanced out by substantial caramel and toffee. Medium - full mouthfeel.

Blast of floral piney hops from the start. Deep amber color. At first a quick dose of bitterness which then switches to a sweet malty finish. Sense a some pepper rye on the tongue. Has that crispy west coast hoppiness to it. Has a refreshing crispiness to it. Well worth a try.
Bottle, pours golden, light head, fairly hoppy stuff, overall quite drink and enjoyed

12 oz bottle. Pours light gold, lager-like to the eye. Aint no lager, though. Thin head that dissipates quickly. Amazing bouquet of peppery/citrus hop, with . . . juniper? Clove like aromas abound. Odd but it definitely works. Medium malt body in the background. The "Jagger" in this brew is/are the hops. A wondrous prickly bitterness coats the palate, bringing out an amazing array of flavors. They abound in the astringent environment. A kick-ass ale. Hard to believe this was a last minute replacement for another brew. It definitely DOES NOT suck. Thank you sir, may I have another.
nice light blond with average head. crisp delicate, and slightly sweet hops. absolutely delicious and really easy to throw back.

Pours rich golden with a tiny white head. Smells piney, resinous, and explodes with citrus. Taste is quite bitter, but not too much so, and has some citrus and pine flavors with hints of a cereal like graininess. Medium-bodied with a slick texture and mild mouth-carbonation, Lagunitas Sucks Holiday Ale finishes with some lingering soft bitterness.
Amber in color with a decent off-white head. Aroma is of citrus, floral, light pine. Taste is the same.

Date: November 25, 2011
Mode: Draft
Source: Taco Mac, Woodstock
Appearance: clear gold, frothy off white head
Aroma: sweet crystal and pine aroma, light peppery spicyness
Flavor: sweet pine flavor enhanced by the crystal malt, touch of spicyness
Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *** /4

Bottle. Poured a darker yellow almost amber color with a smaller white head. Aroma was almost like an IPA. Strong spruce and hops. Flavor was pine, caramel, and hop bitters. Malty up front and hops in the bitters. A very good beer.
Awesome beer.  Love the taste, love the balance of the hops.  I love the hop burst you get and the strong citra flavor.  Very citrus hops but not too bitter.  A favorite of mine the last two months.

Aroma is amazing. Hops forward, dank, smells of pine and grapefruit. Probably one of the best smelling beers I have had. Taste is consistent with the aroma, but less pronounced. Filtered beer, appearance is not anything special. I wish I had more of this and I hope Lagunitas keeps this in their lineup.

WOW!!!!!WHAT IS THIS BEER!!!MY MIND IS BLOWN!! Thanks Jeff for saving me one out of the 60 you bought. Clear peachy gold with a tall rocky crown. MASSIVE peachy hop aroma, pineapple, tangerine, bubblegum, with mild hints of leather. This aroma is epic! Roapy lacing is so very sticky. Taste is so intense, big hop bomb with a leathery malt balance. Pineapple, tangerine, lemon hard candy in the finish. The bitter sneaks up on you, you never really notice it but after a while it builds up and lingers for ever. Pine really shows up in the second half of the bottle, I also just realized that this is supper dry. DAM I WANT MORE OF THESE!!! But some jackass bought the entire stock for the entire city!!!! I know where he lives lets storm his house with pitchforks and jello.

On tap at HopCat, Grand Rapids, MI.  Aroma: YES!  A perfect hop explosion in my nose.  Appearance, clear amber, a little on the light side.  Taste is not as good as the aroma would lead you to believe, but still very good.  A winner.
Amazing tropical aroma and a light golden pour.  Fruity flavor with dry resin palate.  Very tasty brew.

Delicious! Great in bottle & better on tap. Nice sweet hop character. Awesome balance of bitter. 
(Tap/Longfellow Grill) 02/2012

Appearance: Pours a bright hazy amber gold with a white ring around the top. Leaves lacing. 

Aroma: Danky grapefruit, pineapple, pinsol tangerine. 

Taste: Pine and grapefruit bitterness dry spicy malt. 

Mouthfeel: Rough, spicy high carbonation. (editors note: less carbed from the bottle).

Overall: Perfection. Id love it if Lagunitas made room for this all year long. Like Big Bird professed, Keep Christmas With You, All Through The Year.

(12oz bottle from BevMo! Scottsdale).  Pours a clear golden color with an off-white head that cakes itself to the glass.  Thick stuff.  Aroma has some grapefruit, tropical fruits, some resin and a bit of pepperiness.  Taste is sweet with some pleasant bitterness.  Medium bodied and a creamy texture. Very drinkable and quite tasty.

Pours a clear golden with a big fluffy head with lots of lacing.  Huge aroma of pineapple, grapefruit, citrus, and apricot.  Bold flavors of citrus combined with a piney bitterness that is not overwhelming.  Beautiful beer for any hophead.  One of the best IPAs Ive ever had.

I appreciate breweries with a sense of humor, whether subtle or obvious and in the case of Lagunitas Sucks Holiday Ale its clear they were going for irony of Orwellian proportions. It most definitely does not suck, in fact its close to absolute perfection. A beer with amazing, delicious taste, smooth drinkability and is very versatile. The only thing that sucks about this beer is that its not a year-round offering.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass.

Appearance: Bright orange color with only slight haze; some carbonation bubbles visible. Forms a large, bright white, frothy head which retains and laces beautifully.

Smell: Magnificent bouquet of fleshy tropical fruits (i.e. mango, papaya, guava, passion fruit); noticeable sweet candy-like aroma too plus organic flowers. Extremely inviting.

Taste: Sometimes you know a beer is great when you drink it quickly because you enjoy it so much. I drank Lagunitas Sucks Holiday Ale in about five minutes because it was so delectable. The palate matches the nose perfectly: a strong, delightful and delicious palate of tropical fruit, candy sweetness and prominent hop bitterness that doesnt overwhelm. Its akin to tropical fruit juice mixed with hops and Spree candy.

The palate begins with a sharp, somewhat dry hop bitterness. Then the fruit flavors of grapefruit, passion fruit, guava, et al come rushing in. Its a wonderful combination of hop bitterness and hop-derived fruitiness. Im guessing this beer was made with Citra and Amarillo hops. I get a strong orange character which imparts some tartness, but not acidity. Theres noticeable sweetness too, like fruit-flavored sucker candy and it finishes with just a bit of resin or pine on the back end. The hops linger on the tongue and are rather dry, but so do the fruit flavors. A very pleasant sensation all around.

Drinkability: This is a beer that rides that fine line between single and double IPA in terms of robustness and complexity of palate. The hops are the star of the show, as it is quite bitter, but its bitterness reading seems a little low at 63.21 IBUs. The ABV, however, seems a bit high at 7.85%. It doesnt have the bulk or density of a beer that strong and theres no alcohol presence whatsoever. The delicious taste is made even better by the fact the beer feels so comfortable in the mouth and goes down so smoothly. A full-bodied palate for sure, yet it doesnt feel thick or sticky. Lagunitas Sucks Holiday Ale is versatile, too, as it would be ideal for spicy food pairings, but its tasty enough to enjoy as a dessert. Whens the last time you could say that about an IPA?!

S: clear, bronze, color, average carbonation, thin white head

A: floral, citrusy, clean, sweet, hoppy aromas with an almost sticky nose

T: dry, bitter, hoppiness, clean, a little fruit, orange/lemon; nose was deceiving, not as much taste as smell

O: a solid brew, lagunitas has made another good one. This beer is the opposite of "sucks." well balanced, tasty, starts sweet, goes bitter, finishes smooth

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very good  IPA.  West Coast style, which I love.  Better than most but a slight step below the Pliney/Heady Toppers of the world.
Wow. Very surprising beer. Great tropical hops on the nose and throughout the taste. Very smooth and extremely drink able

IPA love in a glass.  Wonderfully pure expression of a classic west coast IPA.  Im not sure what it is about this beer that gets to me so much, but it has an innate balance that makes me not miss Brown Shugga whatsoever.  I hope they "suck" every year.

Keg at Brouwerij Lane, Brooklyn, with Seth. Clear gold pour with a medium, off-white foam head. Sweaty pine hops in the nose, some grapes and other ripe fruits. Wet hay. Big sweet flavor, medium to strong bitterness, pine, ripe citrus, bread. Full bodied with average carbonation. Sticky, oily finish. Big hops all around, big sweetness. Pretty hefty stuff. I like.

Draft at Crunchys, East Lansing. Clear orange-brown body, thin buff head/ring. Big, juicy hops nose with tangeringe and tropical fruit, with bitter notes and alcohol warmth. Crisp, bitter, citrusy body with tangerine and papaya backed by toasty malts, sharpened by prickly alcohol notes. Strong but lean. Very nice.

12 ounce bottle thanks to Craig. Pours a clear copper color with a large white head. The aroma is sweet citrus with tropical fruit. The flavor is a simple and tasty hop forward brew; pineapple, citrus, lingering bitterness, a bit of biscuit. Very smooth. Insanely drinkable.

Huge spruce nose - jumped out of the bottle and drop kicked my nose with a steel-toe boot.  Big sweet malt body. Some herbal and floral qualities.  Strong ripe fruit character.  A bit of pepper on top of tropical notes.  Really nice hop spice and citrus.  This is Lagunitas bread-and-butter;  a perfect example of their balls-out, straight-up muscle car horsepower, bull in the china shop approach that leaves little to the imagination but is dead center bulleye and every other cliche in the book.

Deep orange colored, very clear, and has a decent white head. The aromas are big tropical fruitiness, hops, pineapple, sugar, peach, floral, and great. The taste is medium light bitterness, sugary, resin, grass, hops, and good. Big bright and nice.

Acquired this in a trade from San Francisco. Very stoked! Poured into a Harpoon 100 Barrel Glass at 45 Degrees F. 

A - Two finger crystal clear bubbly head. Light golden color with lots of carbonation floating around

S - Tons of pine like a Double IPA with very sweet notes and a hint of citrus. Theres some earthiness to it as well.

T - Wow. pine, earth tones and lots of brown sugar just come through so easily. Very drinkable like a toned down Pliny the elder but a whole lot sweeter. Theres a bit of citrus on the after taste

M - Huge carbonation explosion on the swish. Medium bodied and very drinkable

O - My expectations in this beer were met. I may not be drinking mine until February but Im so happy this beer came to me even if it was a little past Christmas. Excellent beer and one I hope will return.

Pours a beautiful golden honey which shimmers from the heavy body. Fluffy white head 2 fingers thick. Smells absolutely fantastic. Maybe the best smelling IPA I have ever put my nostrils to.  Very sweet citrus. The spice of the rye malts is present, strong orange citrus notes with spicy, pine, resinous, hop taste. Great balance. Piney hop resin left on the lips. The body is medium-heavy yet the nice citrus balance makes it feel a lot lighter. After taste of strong piney hop resin. One of the best IPAs I have ever had.

maybe the keg i got my pour from was old-ish, but poured at a reputable beer bar, nose was average for an ipa. hints of citrus and fruit rind. taste was pretty run of the mill, bitter, little malt profile at all, light medium body, and discernible c-hop profile. citrusy, but not pungent or resinous. people keep comparing it to pliny, but it was very similar to what i remember racer 5 being. a good ipa, but not the upper echelon.

Light golden orange pour with a long lasting thin foamy white head. Big hop aroma - grapefruit with a tinge of floral and pine. Taste is similar to the aroma, perhaps not quite as hoppy. Very hop forward, but not overpowering, good balance. An excellent ale from this brewer.

12 ounce bottle thanks to Craig. Great aroma of citrus, tangerine, slight grain character. The flavor is similar, a great citrus hop character that its balanced very well against the grain. A great beer.

Holiday leftovers ale. Bottled on 12/30/2011. Poured into a pint glass.

A - Lighter than most DIPAs. Burnt orange body that looks like apple juice. One finger off-white head that sticks around. Nice lacing on the side of the glass. 

S - Reminds me of nugget nectar. Loads of peaches, mango, and grapefruit. Strong on the tropical fruit with a hint of pine and grass towards the end. No malts present.

T - Similar to the nose. Super strong tropical notes that finish slightly earthy and piney. Just a hint of biscuity malts. Long lasting bitter finish. Medium mouth feel, really slick with a nice level of carbonation.

O - I had the original batch back when it came out and thought it was liking drinking orange juice. Maybe its the month that allowed it to smooth out a bit, but this is a damn good DIPA. Really hope Lagunitas brings this back somehow.
Gold pour with creamy white head and lace. Aroma is resiny hops and rock candy. Sweet caramel malt and resiny hops dominate the flavor. Nice carbonation and a medium bodied beer. Pretty nice

Grass and hoppy aroma.  Clear blonde appearance.  Ok lacing.  Taste is very upfront.  Strong hopping finished with bitter hop resin.  Very easy to drink.  Brown Shugga is hard act to follow and this fills in nicely.

Big thanks to Huhzubendah for gifting me a sixer of this. Served in a mug.

Pours a clear golden-yellow color with a nice white head and quite a bit of lacing on the way down. The nose carries a heavy amount of what seem to be Amarillo hops. Good citrus and a bit of a floral character. Similar flavor, but not quite as pungent and overpowering. No malt to speak of, though a bit of booze works through, doing a great job to balance out the hops. No use of sweetness for that here. Boom.

12 oz bottle from Traut frig at the lake...thanks.  Pours Cloudy golden color with major lacing...hoppy nose and initial taste.  Tastes of pine and grapefruit with nice bitter aftertaste...very tasty.
Spectaculaire arôme de pêche juteuse et de gomme de pin. En bouche cest rond avec un profil malté assez étoffé combiné aux notes sapinés. Recette intéressante et très rafraîchissante.
On tap at the boathouse in conshie.   Cloudy orange pour.  Aroma is strong mango, citrus, fruit, strawberries.   Fruity grapefruit, mango, orange.  Its an ipa but a great one. smoke,

Beer pours light orange golden color, small white head and small amount of lace on glass. Smell is great, grapefruit, hops, fruit and pine. Taste is of tropical fruit, hops and pine not to heavy, light to medium carbonation, nice dry finish, great beer.

This will be my 700th.  Another milestone in beer tasting.  This is an interesting ale. The ale poured a clear gold with a frothy head and major lacing. The grapefruit flavors was signifcant.  This is a mouthful of citrus.  The medium body finishs with a bitter aftertaste.  This is a great ale, what a surprise.
Light gold, frothy white head. Aroma of floral hops, caramel, grain, herb. Taste of mild citrus, floral hops, nice beer.

This IPA pours a clear golden, slightly orange color.  Basically no head is poured and very little lacing.  Small amount of carbonation.  The aroma is really nice on this one.  Its full of tropical fruit.  Mango and grapefruit.  Mixed in there is a sweetness from the malt and some honey.

The taste is light and delicate with being full of hops and sweetness.  Tropical fruits again with sweetness from the malt and honey like taste.  Its teetering from being a nice huge hoppy beer but is pulled back a bit from the sweetness.  But its tasty and a joy to drink.

Mouthfeel was actually a tad bit disappointing.  It was very light.  But crisp.  Nice bitter after taste.

Ill take this over Brown shugga anyday. Pours gold with a slight orange tinge. White foam covers the beers surface. Big citrus aromas dominate with a hefty pine scent as well. There are also grainy aromas of caramel. The flavor follows suit. Big citrus and pine resin. The complexity of the malt selection really makes itself apparent. The rye and wheat make a small but welcome apppearance and the oats lend to a wonderful body. I hope this is brewed again. It is a top knotch double ipa.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2014 The aroma wasnt very strong some piney hops and tropical fruits but had to really work my nose since the beer was actually to cold. The taste though was an amazing explosion of grapefruit, piney hops some citrus and orange peel also  lots of hops on this one. The mouthfeel had a very nice carbonation. Overall an amazing brew easy to drink very hoppy with mild bitterness I loved it.
Awesome ale. This is probably the best smelling beer I have had. Tasted very good. I would buy this regularly if it was available.

12oz bottle pour. hits the glass a beautiful orange color with solid off white head. BIG citrus hop aroma, so fresh! sweet pineapple and piney as well. youre hit with an intense citrus flavor, reminiscent of grapefruit from the first taste. bitter on the finish with a nice lil alcohol kick. some sick lacing on the glass and good head retention throughout the glass! great stuff!

Bottle 12oz. Pours clear copper color with minimal head.
Smells of citrus and grapefruit. Taste is mainly pine and citrus hops, little malt taste. Has somewhat soapy mouthfeel and dry dandelion aftertaste. Overall pretty average brew, nuthin worth buying again

12oz bottle picked up in Vacaville 
Appearance: Clear golden with a medium sized white head and good lacing 
Aroma: Tropical fruit and citrus 
Taste: Fruity, citrus and mild biscuity 
Awesome, well balanced and easy drinking Wish I could get this all the time.
Clear golden colour with a frothy white head. Medium carbonation. Fresh fruit hop aroma. Tangy citrus flavour. Quite warming. Pine malt finish. Silky spicy texture.
12 ounce thanks to Jason. Big citrus and orange nose. Lovely hop aroma and taste. Now I know what everyone is talking about. Fantastic.

Bottle shared by MrPickles...thanks Andy! - Pours light amber with a huge foamy white head. Tons of bright citrusy hops, with a smooth pine aroma. A bit of onion in there as well, but in a good way. Real light pale malt--the hops are king here. Taste brings more onion and some garlic--along with a bit of pine and a little firmer, sweeter malt. Tastes like a DIPA--its intense and focuses on the hops. Very nice.

A: Clear pale coppery yellow in color, minimal head. Thin film across the surface and a small ring around the edges.

S: Huge pineapple aroma. Piney and hoppy with a hint of alcohol. Very nice! Intoxicating almost.

T: Taste follows the nose, lots of fruity pineapple flavor, hoppy, piney and a nice sweet fruity malt backbone. DAMN the fruity pineapply flavors are ridiculous!

M: Medium carbonation, creamy mouthfeel, sweet, smooth finish.

O: Lagunitas sucks just plain ROCKS. This DIPA is amazing. I want more.

Aroma is citrusy with a bit of pine.  Beer pours very yellow with slight head.  It is very transparent.  1st sip reveals nice hop spiciness with rich fruit and pine flavors.  Finishes with flavorful fruit esters, almost like apple juice.   Yum
Surprisingly good considering the name.  Never tried the actual holiday brown sugar so nothing to compare to, but this is nice and hoppy and clean.  Maybe not that brown?  More ipa-esque.

Bottle poured into pint.  Appealing golden, orange color...very clear.  Ample soapy head that retains fairly well.  Brilliant aroma.  Crisp, clean, complex.  Full of pine, citrus, pineapple, apricot, orange marmalade, slight caramel.  Full bodied and slightly sticky on the palate.  Pretty bitter all the way thru before a lingering dry finish.  Similar flavor notes as in the aroma plus a nice boozey touch.  More caramel and resin than in the nose and less of the citrus.  An excellent IPA, one of the best ones I"ve had in a while.  Great value, as well!  Wonderful beer...
Tap.  Pours a light gold with a medium head.  The aroma is citrus hops.  The flavor is hops- grapefruit, passion fruit. Very distinctive.  Excellent overall.

Draft at Commercial Taphouse.  Pours a light orange, nice head.  Aroma is a citrus hop bomb, and is pretty awesome.  Flavor is a light malt body, followed by a blast of citrus hops, mostly grapefruit, pineapple, and apricot.  Although the malts are light, they have enough complexity to hold up to the hops.  Sort of like an IIPA.  Very good.  Honestly prefer this over the usual Brown Shugga.

Pours a dark orange, almost amber. Fresh pine and citrus hop aroma. Minimal head. Very smooth, pine and citrus hops from start to finish. And an interesting malt character as well, almost a finishing sweetness.
Piney with a hint of citrus. The taste has a light molases note and a dry finish. This is a nice IPA style ale.

Nice golden color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of rich pine hops, floral, & some citrus. Flavor of slight sweet malt, pine hops, rye, citrus (notably grapefruit), and spice; Finish is bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, more of an IPA - but pretty good.

On tap @ Specific Gravity, Salisbury Md-Golden/orange pour w/a foamy white head.  Aroma of pine hops. Strong pine needle hop flavor, w/some sugary sap, citrus, rye, yeast, & roasted malt. With this much going on, it had the potential to be a cluttered mess (like their Brown Shugga IMHO) but they were able to pull this off. Nice winter saesonal, enjoyable, maybe the lower alcohol made It easier to drink, but this was a good, solid brew.

12oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours amber with a lacy, light beige head.  Aroma of citrusy and piney hops, some caramel and bread malts, and a little light fruit.  Flavor about the same, with lots of hops.  Average texture.  A really good beer, but something doesnt blend well with the malts and hops.

From 12 oz. bottle. Strong grapefruit and grassy aroma. Little carbination and lacing. Golden, slightly cloudy color with a white head. Taste is big hoppyiness and grapefruit with earthy overtones. Good IPA. Will purchase again.
Draft.  Hazy light golden amber, with a off white head.  Grapefruit, sweet fruity candy, cereal, moderate hopping, but not that bitter.  Its okay, too sweet.

at long last i get round to this baby.
12 oz single from Fred Meyer, S.Salem $1.67
Clear orange body to the ale  with a nice half inch sized white frothy head.
Big strong,dank,heavy resiny hop aromas,herbal
Again heavy hop taste but very well matched by the bready,caramel maltiness, but bright citric,lemon zest hops dominate in the end.
Good on the palate  keeps this heavy brew moving
Another Lagunitas classic..to me though this is more a DIPA than an ASA
Nice aroma of hops up front. The taste is a little hoppy, but pleasant.  A little after taste, but fairly mild. Overall a good beer.

12 oz bottle.  Pours nice medium white head, yellow-orange clear body.  Big resin and citrus nose.  Tingly hops mixed with cereal notes at the end.  Medium to full bodied, lingering finish.  Hope they screw this up again in the years to come!

Strong and pungent aroma of pine needle, aloe, and cat piss, but mostly pine. Crystal clear amber, thin head. Flavor is very much like cat piss and cat nip but with a Belgian candi sugar sweetness. Finishes with pine needle. Not resinous, light to medium body. alcohol isnt really noticeable with the overpowering flavors to distract/tantalize/disgust you. my negative first impression often softens by the time I finish the bottle, but this is hard for me to appreciate. I absolutely love the self-deprecating name and label. Sadly, its among the beers few redeeming values.
Bottle. Clear yellow pour with a small white head.  Grapefruit hop aromas.  Well balanced with dank pine and citrusy hop notes that are offset by the sturdy malt backbone..

12oz bottle pours a clear orange with a creamy, white head.  Nose is nice and zesty, garlic shoots, pine, orange zest, limes.  Flavor is sweet, zesty, oranges, pine, honey, grapefruit.  Medium bodied, refreshing, zesty finish.

On tap at Brouwers. Pours a golden honey color, with a smallish head. A hop bomb this one is! Super-smooth for what must be the polar opposite of Brown Shugga. Like a slightly heaver and hoppier version of their standard IPA. Supremely drinkable, and delicious. Very impressed, and Ill take this over Brown Shugga any day of the week.

Tap at Hoppy Monk El Paso Tx-pours bright light orange with a film-y soapy off white head.  nose is floral sugar coated hops lots of flowers and tropical notes.  flavors of candied sweet hops very tropical and a bit spicy from the rye malt.  long floral finish with some astringent resinous notes very lovely mouthfeal.  This is a top-tier beer from this brewery for sure.  love the hop notes on this one.  the floral and tropical aspects make it pretty damn nice.  nice work lagunitas and this DOESNT suck!
Clear amber like colour. hoppy aroma, resin and pine cones. big hoppy flavour with a nice dry hoppy finish. this brewery should suck more often.

12 oz bottle.

It pours a clear gold with just a hint of orange. The head is white and dissipates quickly with no lacing.

The scent is sweet with some melon and citrus.

The flavor is nice. It is fruity with melon and some tomato. The sweetness is there for balance and there is a nice hoppy bitterness in the finish with some grapefruit and pine.

It reminds me of Surly Abrasive. I dont like the tomato summity flavor but other than that it is a good one.

Thanks to Matt for this.  Pours a bright golden with a thin white top and great lacing.  Aroma is big grapefruit hops and light malt.  Taste is well balanced with a strong grapefruit hop bitterness.  I love the stereotypical Lagunitas hop presence.

Tap.  This beer was excellent!  Pours to a glowing golden body.  A sweet looking starched white head sits atop with some beautiful lacing.  Vibrant body.  The aroma is pineapples and some sweet candi sugar.  Mild grass.  The flavor is sweet pineapple and mango with candi sugar and papaya.  The palate is sweet but balanced.  A nice sugary texture.

Bottle. Aroma is big and hoppy, lots of grapefruit rind, perfumey pine. Aromatic hop-driven palate, really nice and fresh, heaps of citrus, some pine resin, crisp and bitter. Im torn-- I love the Brown Shugga, but now I love this too...son-of-a...!!!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle. Pours a clear gold with a fluffy white head that slowly drops leaving sticky lace upon the glass. The nose is an enticing blend of big grapefruit and softer piny hop notes over a sweet pale malt. Medium-bodied and soft with a big tongue-squeezing bitterness at the finish. Like the nose, the flavor is a big hit of grapefruit hops over pale malt with a lingering slightly resinous finish. This is some tasty stuff. I hope they screw up their brewing schedule again next year.

12oz bottle from Discount Liquor Milwaukee, Leftovers packaging. Pours a crystal clear, bright yellow color with a white head and some lacing. Aroma is hoppy, citrus, grapefruit. Citra hops. A little heavy on the palate with average carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, the mixture of grains comes through, nice Citra hop taste, with a nice, clean, bitter hop finish.  Very tasty.

Tasted 1/14/12. 12oz bottle. Pours filtered with a lively golden hue. Tight bubbled white head. Aromas of candied grapefruit hops and other assorted citrus fruit. Full bodied and definitely hop dominant. Nicely sweet and fruity. Good complexity of palate with the sweet, tart and bitter being the most noticeable. Grassy and grapefruity hop flavors with notes of oranges and tangerines. The malt bill is seemingly complex but still overshadowed by the hops. The alcohol is well blended and adds to the overall aesthetic of the brew. Quite nice for a one off.
From growler. Pours light gold with little head and slightly resinous.  Strong beautiful hop aroma. Slight bitterness at the end

12 oz. bottle from Plaza Liquors - Pours a clear golden color with a one finger thick off white head.  Light lacing.  Aroma is floral and pine hops.  Flavor is also floral and pine hops with some malt sweetness in the background.  Finish is somewhat bitter.  Medium body.  A good beer.

Pint @ Chucks. This is just meh. Smells a little bit like weed. A lot of hops and bitterness up front, but then all those malts start to muddle things. Tastes viscous and slightly like a communion wafer. Im a lot of people are going to love this beer but it kind of bores me.

Despite the interesting name, and the even more interesting story behind the name, Ive heard some very nice things about this limited offering and Im curious to try it.  The Lagunitas Sucks Holiday Ale is classified as an American Imperial IPA according to beerAdvocate, which isnt typically my style.  But, Ill give any beer a try at least once.

The Lagunitas Sucks pours out a brilliant golden amber color, with plenty of off-white foam on top.  As the head retreats it leaves behind quite a bit of sticky lacing, generally an indication Im getting myself into something a little too hoppy for my tastes.

The nose reveals plenty of hops, but more reserved than just the typical grapefruit variety.  Theres also an interesting layer of citrus hops aromas, as well as some subtle floral hops.  The aromas keep me guessing as well, something else in there is hard for me to put my finger on.  Im thinking its a some sort of bready or yeastiness, but I cant say for sure.

The flavors are, in no uncertain terms, incredible. The flavors follow the aromas nicely: lots of complexity in the hops, with something unique that I cannot nail down.  Theres a decent amount of hop-bitterness, but its much softer than expected.  The alcohol is fairly obvious for being only about 8% abv.  Theres a nice little bit of malts in the background, but the hops still take charge and lead the way.

Of the dozen or so winter releases Ive had this year, so far the Lagunitas Sucks is my favorite.

As a fan of the original "Brown Shugga" (not the over hopped version that was available last year), this caught my eye. I was able to have a quick sample before purchasing and Im glad I did. 

A - Wonderful lemon, citrus, and pine

T - Lightly bitter with a smooth grapefruit flavor. 

P - Very cleansing to the palate. This would be great with a dish that has a viscous component like a gravy. 

O - I really liked this beer and if it were a little cheaper, I probably would buy more. At $10 for a six there are other options. I also do not like many of Lagunitas offerings, so this was a pleasant surprise. Id bring this to a party for something a little different.
Bottle.  Clear brown orange pour with thin head and much lacing.  Aroma is rich grain, sugar and resin. Very full bodied flavour.  A certain piney note in the finish
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Bottle.  Pours bright gold and orange with a foamy 2-finger head.  Aromas of....mmmm, Christmas tree!  Tons of pine needle and sugary sap, citrus, and some tropical funk.  The flavor is spicy spruce and pine sap, moderately bitter, with a sweet piney finish.  Nice!  Some earthy malt in the aftertaste.  Warming, nearly creamy.  Really nice, a great winter seasonal.  [919]

Amber in color, clear with a thin head.  Big aroma, flavor and wonderful finish.  Nothing sucks about this beer.  Other than that Lagunitas will have to make this all the time.  Sucks to be them.  Great strong ale and terrific new beer to add to there taps.
On tap at the Brass Tap, pours a golden yellow color with aromas of hops, tropical fruit and more hops.  Flavor is all hops in my opinion, and I could only taste that.

Big huge hoppy nose. Fruity as all get out. Tropical fruits peaches apricots citrus oranges and grapefruit. Light sweetness from the malt base adds balance. Fuck yeah. Pours brilliant well filtered golden with a wispy head and lace. Super fruity citrus and tropical fruots apricot peach grapefruit. Pale malt touch of oat sweet smoothness. Dry fruity resinous finish. Quenching. Awesome chuggable. More or less an ipa.
Another good, not great, fruity ipa-like strong ale from Lagunitas.  They dont necessarily have a wide range, but they do good stuff in it.

clear golden with a big white head that is sustained for a while, excellent lacing and or glass drying... loads of tropical and stone fruits, light pale malts, tho the fruits dominate the aroma, not very piney... lively medium body loads of fruits, spicy, stonefruits, tropical fruits moreso than citrus... slick mildly creamy smooth mouthfeel for an IPAish beer... Medium to medium full bodied... AWESOME

Bottle thanks to jleblanc. Almost clear gold, slightly hazy with white head. Aroma is a wonderfull intense blend of tropical fruits (mandarine, pinneaple) with nice rye and pine / hop resin twist. Flavor is less intense and interesting than the nose. Still very hoppy but balanced nicely with cereal and malts so its not overly bitter. Lively carbonation but unfortunately, the body is thin. Very good. It felt more like an IPA/IIPA than an American strong ale. Leans more towards hops than malts.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2014 This is an over the top dry hopped beer with a light body and creamy texture. It smells more or less like a certain mood enhancing aromatic herb and finishes with crisp bitterness keeping it quite drinkable despite its ABV encroaching upon the eight percent mark. I havent read the other reviews yet but let me join what I am sure is a growing crowd that is clamoring for this stuff to be brewed instead of Brown Shugga every year.

crystal clear amber pour with a thin cream/off white head.  nose is hops, more hops, hops, sweet tropical fruits, sticky, and delicious.  excellent on the palate, fresh hop flavor backed by piney resin, tropical fruits, and a lightly sticky finish.  wow

Bottle. Pours a cloudy light amber with frothy white head. On the Nose there is loads of citrus:mandarin orange,ruby red grapefruit, along with some cinnamon,sticky buds and toasted bread. On the palate the beer has a mildly roasty malt flavor with more of that delicious citrus fruit spice combination as well as dankweed/resin. For me this beer is almost as much about the texture as the flavors. there is a creaminess at the beginning that gives way to a slight prickly quality at the end. Have had this a few times and find myself smiling and looking at the glass after every sip. Another winner from Lagunitas.

Draft. Pours golden orange with a white head. Hoppy and fruity aroma with floral and citric notes. The flavor as flowery notes and sweet citrus hops, with some lighter malty sweetness. Very drinkable, really good stuff.

Bottle from sixer. Golden amber pour with white good size head. Aroma is malt sweetness and citrusy hops orange peel, grapefruit. This beer is so smooth and well balanced on the palate. Taste is sweetness and some syrup texture with a citrus hop explosion that doesnt overwhelm. Finishes dry but not piney dry. Its a delicious beer and I could care less about brown shugga.

Bottle. Pours a glowing cider gold with standard white head and gentle white lacing. Aroma is rich of pineapple, passion fruit, pine, and more pineapple. Flavor is awesome pineapple juiciness. Some supporting notes of orange peel with a moderate spruce rush. The finish has a definite hops prominence without going full blown sting, complemented by loads of pineapple juice and orange peel. Fucken hell this is good!
Probably the best beer Lagunitas makes.  Herbal citrus hop aromas.  Tropical citrus hop flavors.  Overall a fantastic beer.

Amber pour with a thin white head. Aromas of grapefruit, orange, lemon, pine and slight rye. Flavors of citrus up front with an oddly metallic bitter finish...really good, but the finish is sorta odd.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2015 On tap, served in a pint glass at Jackie-Os. Clear yellow color, very nice thick foamy white head. Light carbonation, great dry texture. Awesome hop nose here, but not too bitter... Very smooth. Great lace left behind, here. A really awesome and hoppy ale thats too smooth to be called an india pale 8/4/7/4/16 Update rate,  12/21/15: 12oz bottle. Code reads 50915B0061230. Clear orange color, with a finger of white head. Leaves good, thick ridges of lace. Musty metallic kind of bready flavor up front, with some spicy resiny, mild citrusy hops. Moderate-plus bitter taste. Lighter to moderate sweet. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, kind of slick lighter carbonation. Hoppy, but theres a noticeable sweet malt and mild bite in the finish you see from some DIPAs. Decent to enjoy with my subway.

12oz bottle pours clear deep gold with copper core and thin white head. The aroma offers up a bold mix of sugary malt sweetness, spicy hops, citrus hops and earthiness creating a classic liter box aromatic. The taste is similar with rich spicy hops and citrus hop extract blending into a modest level of sugary sweet maltiness. I can drink a load of this!
On tap at square burger.  Pours a golden amber with a thin white head.  The aromas are grapefruit, pine, bread.  The mouthfeel is dry, bitter and has a medium body.  Great brew!  Cheers!

Bottle. Pours amber gold with very little head. Aroma is resin, perhaps with a hint of orange. Near full bodied, thinning as the carb leaves. Flavor is resin over rye? Its not excessively sweet, and seems pretty astringent. Lots of hop in here fer sure. Certainly not a spice/veg/herb xmas ale!

12oz bottle.  Courtesy of Andrew for this surprisingly pretty tasty treat... pours a hazy apricot orange hued consistency with a medium transparency and topped with a thin film of frothy white head...semi-sweet citrus fruits encompass the nose, oranges and tangerines while solidly backed up with crystal malt like notes and a light bready malts.  rather sweet but solid. an odd metallic note develops as the beer warms which clashes with the aforementioned but fades after additional time in the glass... flavors show a slight improvement although ultimately more of the same.  bready grains with a cleanish level of sweetness while melding fairly well a solid citrus hop backing.  a mild to medium level of bitterness surfaces and lingers on through the finish.  fluffy mouthfeel with a more medium bodied consistency.  quality product overall and very consistent from start to finish although the hops lack that fresh dank punch that ive been seeing from the likes of three floyds, alpine, or hill farmstead.
A clear golden orange beer with a small white head.  The aroma is amazing, lots of citrus and pineapple.  The flavor is fruity, floral, bitter, and just a little grainy.  An excellent beer.

Bottled on 12/16/11

Purchased @ Julio Liquors, Westborough Ma

Price - $10.99/sixer

A clear honey orange pour reveals a soapy one inch head with average retention. A steady stream of bubbles rise from the middle of the flared tulip glass and when swirled release another fresh layer of sudsy foam. A beautiful looking double with amazing clarity and big time lacing, very nice.

The nose is a fruit cocktail full of citrus hop aroma. Orange, grapefruit, pineapple and pine scent combine to make a pleasent smell. 

The taste pretty much mirrors the nose with an added hop bite thats pleasing. A tropical blast up front followed by orange peel poured over a caramel malt backbone.

Mouthfeel starts out clean and a little syrupy with a medium body. The carbonation is surprisingly low considering the bubbles and the end reveals a pleasent bitter finish. 

Overall I really dig this beer fresh. Lets get this one in the line-up please and get it to NH.

355ml bottle. Pours a clear, semi-dark gold with almost white head thats a little short but leaves a good lace. Lots of grapefruit and spruce sap on the nose with a caramel back and what seems to me to be candi sugar. A little sweet on the palate and a big letdown from the nose. Theres some good hops but something offsets them. Definitely good but ultimately odd brew.

12oz bottle 1/6/12 (Binnys Downers Grove)-38° in Snifter-Pours clear medium golden with a small white head. Aroma of hops, citrus, grapefruit, and a touch of carmel. Taste of the same with more hops citrus coming thru. This medium bodied brew is well balanced and is another kick butt brew from these guys.

Bottle, from my Hennepin glass. Pours clear honey-gold; 1-finger white head, spotty to good lacing. Nose is lifted citrus: Grapefruit, persimmon, lemon, cold cream, and juniper/spruce. Killer nose. Flavours of sticky hop cones, honey-malt, lots of citrus just bouncing around in this one. Damn tasty.

A - pours clear apple juice golden, with 1 finger white head of tight bubbles that disperses quickly. Some lingering.  

S - aromas of tropical fruit, guava and passion fruit, followed by tropical/citrus hops, lightly grassy and spicy notes.

M - light medium body with some carbonation. Lightly oily. Fairly short lived ending.

T - citrus and piney hops on the nose, subtle tropical fruits and lightly spicy hops on the palate. Tropical fruits and caramel malts on a brief end. Subtle basic notes throughout( slightly soapy notes)

O - very good ipa, with nice tropical fruits. 

6+/7-
Sweet, malty and string hops. Amarillo delicious. Grassy hops balanced by a little Maltiness. Foamy and delicious.

4 Jan 2012, bottle. pale gold, clear, steady bubbles, thin foamy head. absolutely gorgeous nose! not aggressive but prominent grassy hops, moderate alcohol and some caramel toast notes. med body and a bit fizzy. slightly syrupy tasting, fizziness somehow cuts into the taste. not much in the middle w a bitter, grassy finish. okay.

Pours a clear yellow with an orange tint.  Very small white head.  Good lacing.  
Smells of citrus, a touch of caramel, spice, lime, hops, some floral, and malt in the back.
Taste is bitter and a little sour, pine,  caramel, malt, and spice.  Ends nicely bitter.

Bottle. Moderate malt notes of roasted and caramel, moderate to heavy pine and grapefruit for the hops, light soap for the yeast with hints of wood, pepper, medicine and a mix of dried fruit. Head is average to large, frothy, slightly off-white with good lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is sparkling clear light amber. Flavor starts slightly sweet and moderately acidic, then the fairly long finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately to heavily bitter and a touch sour. Palate is light to medium, a little slick with a lively carbonation and a tart aftertaste. I wasnt expecting this much complex American Strong Ale aromas and flavors from a Holiday Ale, which only gets more prominent as it warms a bit.

Tap, Tap room 307, Gramercy, NYC, 17/12/11. Clear gold piled with foam. Deeply green, leafy, lemon and grapefruit zest aroma. Utterly piney, lean and honeyed. Sherbet and lemon zest impressions. So clean and good, even after a fairly exhaustive trawl around town. Beautiful.

This is aptly named, it really does kind of suck
Deep gold,lasting white head.Cat piss nose and palate. Astringent citrus hop profile, poorly balanced, devoid of malt.One dimensional

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2014 Pours clear gold with off white lacey foam. Smell is sweet with grapefruit peach rose and various grains, more floral with age, along with than classic lagunitas yeast smell (and taste). The taste is slightly bittering and a little herbal with piney pineapple mostly with a sweet golden malt caramel grain. There is a grain heavy palate and a residual sweetness in all of it, a few months sitting has increased the grain and mellows the hops quite a bit from the freshly distributed brew. I can see this being a bit thrown together but still very nice and easy to drink. If you like most of lagunitas?s beers you?re going to enjoy this.

Thin white head. Retention is fair as is the lace. lightly hazy amber/copper hued ale. Nose is grainy malt with some light citrusy notes, bit much on the crystal malt. Body is med/full, soft carbonation, lil chewy. Grainy malts, lightly sweet with a citrusy, piney hop charge. Lil cat pee goin on, earthy and fruity. Fairly bitter finish. Not sure what all the fuss is about? Bottle procured @statelineliquors.

12 oz. bottle from my Secret Santa- thanks, Santa! Pours a clear gold with an inch of just barely off-white uneven head that laces the glass a good deal. Aroma of big herbal and oily hops, orange, citronella, and sweet malts. Flavor of herbal and oily hops, winter spices, rye, orange, and fresh leaves. Light-medium bodied, with a bitter, smooth, and dry mouthfeel. Moderate carbonation. Really nice winter IPA.

Courtesy of craftycarl21. A clear golden pour yields a frothy white head with decent retention. Excellent hop character! Citrusy herbals, nectar fruits, fruit cocktail, and a hint of resin lead to a subtle caramel malt profile. Juicy citrusy resinous finish. Medium body with great carbonation. This beer is surprisingly great!
Draft at Mellow Mushroom Charlottesville. Pours orange with some pine on the nose. Nice hop flavor with some nice holiday spice. Clean finisher.

Love the humorous description for the ale, but no apology needed as this is one fantastic brew.  Pours a pale copper with minimal white head (left a nice ring and small island of foam in the center) and a small bit of lacing.  Nice nose with pine, citrus and pineapple.  Good mouthfeel due to the lively carbonation.  Taste is full of hops with a good malt backbone.  Somewhat resinous reminding me a bit of Maximus.  Clean and crips finish with moderate lingering bitterness.  Not the typical winter brew, but a nice change of pace from one of my all-time favorite breweries.

Has a really tart, sour edge that I wasnt exPecting.  It fades out of your mouth quickly without tarting up your mOuth. Quite cleAr with just some swirlis at the bottom. Has that wierdness that seems gross at first but you have to keep on trying...

Bottle. Heard a lot about this and seemed right to be drank on New Years Ever. Pours a light medium colored copper color with a thick white head. Nice head retention. Some lace. Nice citrus aroma in the nose. Malty backbone with a nice citrus rind. NIce level of bitterness. Ends pretty crisply and cleanly with a minimal lingering bitterness. Dangerously drinkable.

Drawn to the bottle by the somewhat clownish Santa label. To my palate this beer rates as an imperial IPA more than a winter ale. Great nose followed by a strong hop beginning and finish. After a couple I got around to reading the rest of the label and found the warmth in my head was just right to let out a few guffaws Would buy again..

Bottle, as pictured  Pours a clear golden-orange with minimal white head.  Smells surprisingly piney, though theres not a ton of hops in the flavor.  Lots of spice in it, very peppery.  Pretty good, would definitely buy again.

Very honest, humorous and unnecessary explanation is given for this beers existence. The brewers growth is good news for hopped beer fans. This one looks like an amber or pale ale and has the brewers signature dry hop pine notes and grapefruit scent. The latter really comes through in the taste, followed by a long bitter finish. Wheat presence is a bit confusing. Not as stinging as Lagunitas 70+ IBU IPAs, and a little lighter bodied. A good brew to finish off the beer year. Now to go and drink freaking champagne.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2013 Not your typical hioliday brew, this one tasted more like a cider with pleasing carbonated delivery. Juicy hop aromas and pleasing grapefruit flavors, this beer is fresh and satisfying.

Bottle, pours clear light gold with foamy white head. Aroma is really hoppy, bright green citrusy notes, clementines, pine, with an earthy faint nutmeg in the background. Too bad the Flavors arent as green and bright as the aroma but there still fresh clementines and grapefruit rind, sugar cubes, rye, and again a really faint nutmeg back there. Reminds me of a poormans zombie dust, its good but quite a bit sweeter, itll do while ZD is out right now.

On tap at the brewpub. Gold in color with an aroma of floral hoppiness. Typical Lagunitas brew with slight bitterness and some sweet suguary goodness. Better than average, but just not as good as the brew it was supposed to replace.

Aroma - tropical mango
Appearance - golden to amber
Taste - light sweetness, medium bitterness
Palate -  medium body, average carbonation, bitter
Awesome, my current favorite DIPA
Quite similar to Little Sumpin Sumpin in my opinion.  Hoppy base with tangerine, citrus, with a rye finish.  Very drinkable beer here.  A fine replacement for Brown Sugga.

Love the description on this one.  Poured into a snifter glass.  Color is gold with a very thin white head.  Aroma is complex with strong pine notes from the hops, some sweet sugariness in the background, and a hint of a tropical aroma of some sort.  Flavor starts with some sweetness and transitions into some of the wheat and rye flavors through the middle, then finishes with some resinous hop notes.  Medium bodied and smooth for the ABV.  Overall I think this substitute beer deserves to have a home alongside Brown Shugga in Lagunitas future winter offerings.

Courtesy of Styles 
Bottle: The aroma is loaded with cirrus hops, tropical fruits, pineapple, and grapefruit. It pours a transparent gold with a small white head. The flavor starts with lots of tropical fruits and pineapple. The finish lots of orange and citrus hops. Medium bodied with mild carbonation.

12oz bottle courtesy of Styles. Pours crystal clear with almost no head, leaving a small white ring around the glass. Aroma is huge piney hops. Not really my thing. However, the flavor isnt nearly as bitter, or resiny as I expected. Actually quite nice. Firmly bitter, with both piney, and citrusy hops. Nice medum body with a clean finish.

Gold with a surprising amount of floaties, thin white head.  Nose is mango, pine resin, mint, dank, alcohol.  Really big.  Flavor is pine, tropical fruit (mango, pineapple), strong bitterness, dank.  Sweet honey malt backs it all up.  Lingering bitterness with dank, mint & pineapple skin.  Nice!

Pours a clear lemon yellow with frothy white head that dissipates fairly quickly. Aroma definite pink grapefruit, yeasty bread dough and pepper. Flavor is citrusy grapefruit, mild raisin, earthy florals. Body is light with a lot of carbonation. Yummy.

Had this one At the Eastaide tavern about 3 weeks ago and have been waiting for the release of this one every day scents.   I think this is one of the most floral hop bombs this brewery has put out yet. Its like hop stupids little brother with more of a grapefruit twist and much more easy drinking.   Dont get me wrong I worship the brownsugga every year but hopefully they start releasing every year also.       Please

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2013 Golden color in the glass with a nice head. The aroma has a sweetness up front with honey, citrus and pleasent hops. Taste is fantastic. It has a candy like quality of caramel and citrus. There is some faint pine and malt. The finish is ultra smooth and has a great finish. Picked up 3 sixers so far and going for more.

Gold orange color with thin white head, strong citrus fruit aromas, lots of orange and hints of lemon. Taste is pretty hoppy with citrus and pine notes, slight caramel malt finish, strikes me as more of an IPA. Good beer

Sprucy and orange aroma of hops. Pale amber color with white head.  Taste is balanced and smooth.  Strong pine taste with come caramel malt undertones.  The bitterness is throughout but a definite lasting.  I enjoy it.

Clear light amber color/ ivory sheen. Pine, grassy, grapefruit, spicy caramel aromas. Medium bodied with soft co2. Pine sap, citrus, floral hoppy flavors in a spicy caramel, lightly sweet base brew, nicely bitter finish--good
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text:
Tangerine, orange, citron, mint leaf in the nose. Very spicy rye bread, pepper, green onion. Sweet with a balanced base.

The appearance is pale yellow, with a big head and watery lace. A ton of carbonation.

The flavor is peppery rye malt, followed by spicy orange peel and grapefruit. Tea leaves, with a very bitter finish, but in a sweetly perfumey way.

The palate is slick, and thicker than you might think because its so smooth. A superior, citrusy ale with a beautiful balance. Terrific.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2012 12oz bottle.
Golden orange with a good amount of white head.  Great nose of pine and resin - flavors of grapefruit and other citrus fruits.  Good amount of bitterness and nicely balanced.  I hope they continue to brew this beer every year as I really enjoyec it.

Bottle shared by a friend. Pours a clear gold with a medium white head. Aroma of spicy hops to the point its giving off some onion notes. Some malt in there as well. Malty and oniony flavor with a bit of booze and an apricot character before a grapefruit finish.

they were right, this did suck. +++ Sampled on draft at the Headkeeper in Greensburg PA this beer poured a yellow-amber color with a medium sized foamy off white head that lingered and left good lacing. The aroma was intensely strong catbox and windex with no redeeming features. The flavor redeemed itself a bit with semi-sweet pine, resin and lemon and moderate notes of perfume, windex and table sugar. The finish was long with mixed hops and turned a bit dry. Moderately full bodied.. Yep, it sucks.
this beer is major hop head, the aroma is pure citrus. lots of grapefruits. taste is straight forward hoppiness yet with very little astringent aftertaste. this beer is for the hardcore hop head.

The aroma is super hoppy with grass, pine, and citrus. There is also malt to balance but this one is all about hops. The appearance is golden with an average head. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is smooth. Overall this definitely doesnt suck.

This poured a bright darker yellow color with a white head. Aroma was lots and lots of piney and fruity dank hops. They smell ridiculously fresh.  Flavor was much the same except a little subdued and grainy.  Not much in the way of malt at all, just straight hop water. Yum. Lagunitas, masters of hop extract.

Strong grapefruit aroma. The pour from a 12oz bottle is a frothy white head with amber liquid.  The taste is citrus with hop bitterness balanced by malty sweetness.  Good carbonation.  An excellent IPA from Lagunitas...Im curious about their recipe.

Bottle. Amber beer with a cream colored head. Tropical fruit/summer fruit aroma with grapefruit and light caramel. Tropical fruit/summer fruit flavor with grapefruit and sweet caramel. Medium bodied. Nice bitterness. Tropical and summer fruits linger with grapefruit and sweet caramel.

Ho Ho Holy shit this is good beer.  Lagunitas has long made IPA after IPA Id sell my left lung for, and now theyve come up with an accidental seasonal that may be one of the best IPAs Ive drank in years.  This big, piney, citric, minty beast has whole cone hops wafting up  in the aroma, backed by a huge orange sweet roll.  And Lagunitas Sucks tastes, well, it tastes like a damn fine IPA should, immensely bitter and dry, yet the huge hops also have a mild sweetness that couples perfectly with the smorgasboard of malts.  To hell with Brown Shugga.  The only way Lagunitas can suck is if they quit brewing this delicious pint before me.

Several bottles and several pints in, I can now agree with the masses that Lagunitas sucks the balls. This is a preemptive suck conclusion though, for when this "replacement" beer disappears from the market. Put Brown Shugga on strike again, because this beer is loads better. ASA my ass, this is a gloriously DIPA with just the mildest of quirky deviance courtesy of the rye and oats. Big, booming, and floral, its elegant, balanced, and massively refreshing. Kudos for the honest self-appraisal and keep this one in the rotation.

Bottle. Fluffy white head with solid retention on a lightly hazy light marigold orange. Lots of resinous and herbal hoppiness with some slight sherbert, in a good way.  Flavor very much follows suit and very dank with lots of resin.  Herbal and oily.  Body is a little slick and medium with nice carbonation.  Lagunitas, please make this every year in place of Brown Shugga.

Hazy light amber.  Slightly chewy, herbal aroma.  Light body, not sticky.  Minty, slightly herbal.  Almost refreshing, even, and its been a long time since I said that about a beer from these guys.  Good.
Bottle.  Golden pour.  Citrus all over this along with some nice front and back end hop bite.  Pretty well balanced.
Delicious.  Citrusy notes, crisp, clean finish, nicely balanced, smooth from the oats.  A delicious beer.

Growler from Consumers Beverages in Buffalo. Pours a very light ambar colour with white foamy head, and some lace. Aroma is hoppy with grapefruit and citrus fruit, some malt and traces of spice. flavour is quit e hoppy, but not overpowering. Grapefruit dominates, with spice and malt lingering in the aftertaste.

I liked it, but not sure what the fuss is about.  Surely this is nothing special.  Big nose of pine and mainly citrus, grapefruit in particular.   Dark gold, some lacing.  Resinous sharp taste is a tad hoppy, a tad of pine needle suckage and then your mouth feels dry from the hops.I like IPAs but how bout some subtleties as a secondary approach.

moderately pungent rye and citrus aroma with some turpentine and an Earthy funk. quenching mouthfeel with little fizzle of carbonation on the tip of my tongue. tastes like it smells even more pronouned. it is a light pale golden like a cream ale and pours like one. Perhaps a flowery funk of old flowers. appealing in its deviation from the norm. makes you want a good cigar.

Had this at the 2011 Pittsburgh Ratebeer Christmas Eve Eve Tasting.   Smells like the body odor of your favorite girl after hard sex.  Perhaps there is some floral hops perfume in the background. Looks like pale lager in appearance. First taste is super hoppy and on style. Yes big time roto tiller plowing down my throat leaving a bitter wake. There seems to be some co2 in the appearance but its certainly lacking in this soapy mouth coating oily palate. Yes, terribly on style.  If you like IPA and havent had this monster that borders on IIPA territory, go for it and ignore my numerical slam.  As stated however, for a lager lover, this beer literally sucks.....
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Nice pine aroma from an amber pour with a small head. The flavor has a nice malt beginning which gives way to a big hop finish. Nice after taste lingers for a while. Im not sure where the holiday aspect comes in but not to worry, a very good beer nonetheless.

draft at Coles, Buffalo NY. Lighter copper pour, golden notes. Great big piney grapefruit aroma. Sticky hops abound. Flavor has a sharpe fresh piney bitterness, garden weediness (a good thing) . Nice big hop flavor, no qualms about this beer. Hops, hops hops

Super clear copper coloured body with an orange glow and a thinnish off-white head. Aroma of bright citrus and grapefruit hops, some alcohol, malt and a little spice. Medium-bodied; Very bright hops at first with a nice kick, showing tons of bitterness, some malt, but mostly a nice bright hop kick. Aftertaste shows a nice rounded flavour with the emphasis on the hops and a touch of malt and sugars. Overall, a nice beer with a ton of hoppiness and a bright glow. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Total Wine in Tustin, California on 06-December-2011 for US$1.99 sampled at home in Washington on 24-December-2011.

Tap @ PW. Clear gold pour with a short, persistent white head leaving heavy lace. Fresh hop nose with maybe some seasonal spices in there? Medium-heavy body with moderate carbonation. Pine, caramel, resin, tropical fruits, ganja and toast. Finish is nicely balanced between bitter, sweet and umami and leaves you wanting more. Ive followed the sad tale of the Lagunitas shipping disaster (being a relative term) and loved the Brown Shugga last year, but am very pleased with this substitute, which I earnestly hope becomes an annual brew. Slightly bettered by Lukcy Basartd, but not by much.

Draft @ Malones. Paler gold, white head. Aroma is so interesting. The hop combines new Zealand delicate grassiness and white grape with marijuana. Intriguing. The flavors are not as well developed or expressed and body is thin but still a nice beer.

Sampled on 12/24/2011. This American Strong Ale pours a deep orange gold color from a 12oz bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head with nice lacing and good retention. The aroma is caramel, fruity and sweet, peaches, mango and some other tropical fruit with some very aggressive citrusy hops. A medium to lighter bodied American Strong Ale. The malts are fruity and sweet, very tropical. The hops are citrusy and grapefruity. Good carbonation. A very fruity, yet very hoppy beer, that is nicely balance between the two extremes. Niuce crisp and dry finish adds to the hop bite. Not your usual beer from Lagunitas, and definitely not your typical holiday beer. I will miss Brown Sugga this year, but this is more than a respectable replacement. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean, dry and crisp. Aftertaste is bitter.

Bottle. What an amazing beer!!! The nose is very citrusy. Amber in color. There is a nice balance of hops in the taste that bring out lots of tropical fruits. Thank you Lagunitas for making my holiday a great one.

12oz bottle. Lots of clean alcohol, onion, garlic, pine and a little fruit in the aroma. Definitely a good dose of dry hopping but not my favorite hop expression. The flavor is big and moderately bitter with a fruity, yeasty thing going on and a little alcohol, but the booze is relatively well hidden. I guess Ill stick with hop stupid. Too bad thats not in sixers. As a pale, hoppy, strong beer that is a stand-in, this isnt bad, but the hops could definitely be tweaked in the future.

12oz bottle. I wasnt sure if this would live up to the hype thats been surrounding it but it most certainly did. Great hoppy aroma with hints of citrus and pine. Flavor/body is a little light but it makes for a great easy drinking beer.

Clear golden brown, thin white head. Fruity aroma, lemon-lime, apricot and some pine notes. Very nicely balanced. Crisp bitterness, some floral touches and a light grapefruit pith flavor. Full mouth feel, without being overladen with malty sweetness. Good stuff.

Bottle Clear golden ale with a small, wispy, white head. Good retention. The aromatic highlights are pineapple, pine and pink grapefruit. Full-bodied and creamy with airy carbonation. The flavor tilts bitter, but not by much. Rindy, pithy hops nearly balanced by tea biscuit and toffee malts. Finishes fruity, piney and lightly bitter. Bottle courtesy of biggsbowler!

Bottle from Vienna Whole Foods.  Pours a clear pale yellow with an orange tint and good carbonation and a nice white head.  Piny aroma with tons of grapefruit and tangerine.  Flavor is slightly with sweet and pine and citrus.  Overpowering bitter finish.  Excellent double IPA.

Oh my this surely smells like christmas, I feel like I am in a pine forrest. This is great because on this christmas eve I returned home only to find that my mother had a non traditional pink artificial christmas tree! This is a very hoppy but good beer.

Bottle from Canals Marlton. Pours out a nice dark copper color with a small white head. Aroma is of nice tropical fruits, light sweet malts, caramel, cereal. Taste is light fruity hop notes, some caramel, grainy notes, light toffee and a decent bitterness on the finish. Solid brew.

shimmering gold, thin white head, spotty lacing. Nose is heavy resin, grassy, light cheese and cracker. Flavor is light melon and resin, cracker ad oats mid, bit of caramel sweetness in the finish. Not too sweet, dryness preserved in end though a bit simple and some sweetness creeping in.

I am a big fan of home brewed, hop forward IPAs. This was surprisingly on par with some of the best home brew that I have sampled. It was so good that I am making plans to stock up on this to last me well after the holidays. Very happy right now.

Bottle. Poured a clear medium orange color with a white head. Pleasant fruit-dominated hop aroma that included the likes of grapefruit, orange, and melon. There was also some cereal grain. Medium bodied and dryish with moderate bitterness. Pine, orange zest, and pale malt/cereal flavors.

2L growler from Bills in Summerville.  Mild (-er than expected) yet solid hop nose. Juicy, citrus, hop forward beer held strong w/ mild (yet solid) malt backbone. Holds its own against way bigger IPA/DIPA. Fukc Brown Sugar this will work...this year.

12oz bottle: pours a clear bright golden with a stringy-lacing white head. Has a huge fresh resiny hoppy nose with good lightly toasted maltiness underneath and some honeydew melon character.  Starts with pretty good fullness and clean malty sweetness with lots of piny hop flavor and bitter balance before a drier more bitter and lingering finish.  I love the hoppy aroma, but the finish could be a little less bitter.  Nonetheless, a great IPA that I hope they make more of.

On tap at brewpub. More piney than floral hops abound in a somewhat mute fashion in this one. Very good AMA hoppy, fresh beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Clear golden in color... Aroma is floral hops... Flavor is slightly watery and bready, with a nice bitter finish... Really unremarkable, not a holiday ale at all... Tastes more like a pale ale than anything... Lagunitas, you suck, bring back the Brown Shugga!!!

12oz bottle at wolfeys for the Parker holiday party, nose is citrus and bright it smells wonderful taste is a bitter medly of rye and wheat with the hops still owning everything this beer is sweet!!! As in awesome
Clear golden, white cover.  Aroma is resin, pine.  Taste is the same resin, some light toast.  Very nice.

On tap at Petrol Station. Pours a clear orange golden with medium frothy off white head. The aroma is floral hops and wheat. Thin mouthfeel with a dry hop and citrus with nice lingering dry finish. Hides the alcohol well, easy to drink, a very impressive American strong ale from Lagunitas.

KILLER BEER! Huge floral aroma- perfectly clear dark yellow to mild orange color, so inviting. Taste is like a huge fresh hopped IPA, Im not sure why this isnt classified as a double/imperial IPA. I really like Hop Stoopid and this is just better all around. Huge flavors of pear and orange; great malt profile that provides a full body beer. This stuff is awesome!

Beer is damn good.  Ive never had brown shugga, so I dont know what Im missing, but I hope they make this one again.  Its a great IPA, really, with an awesome hop aroma and clean, bitter palate.  Very refreshing.  What makes it unique is the compelxity of the malt...cereal as they call it.  Doesnt look like much but has a grea flavor and awesome west coast hops.

12oz brown bottle. Pours out a fairly clear golden with a full white head. Spotty lace. Nose is piney, big citrus, sweet tropical fruits. Taste has up front hops - pine, citrus peels, also has a decent malt character, a bit of bread/grain, some chewiness. Ends bitter. Long and strong hoppy aftertaste with some pine, grapefruit and orange peel in the throat. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Very drinkable, approaching chuggable, no signs of alcohol, overall a nice hoppy strong ale that has nothing to do with the holidays, but everything to do with being tasty. Lagunitas needs to keep this around.

12 oz bottle purchased at Royal in Kansas City, Missouri.  The pour is a mostly clear golden yellow with a 1/2 inch white head.  The head falls with decent lacing.  The aroma is dank resinous hops, lightly bitter and a bit catty.  As it warms, some sweet mango fruit comes out as well.  Fresh nose.  The taste is the resin bitter hops up front, along with cereal grain and Rye.  A bit of the mango sweetness pops out late in the taste.  The palate is medium bodied, resinous dry and bitter in the finish.  Nice one, reminded me of Double Jack.

Thanks to Cletus for the hook up. Near orange pour with a small white head, very clear. Fruit forward hop aroma with a nice malt background showing up. You know, this isnt quite the tropical fruit hop bomb Ive been loving lately, but it still has a bunch of great citrus going on as well as a almost appley fruit zest going on. I guess thats not quite it, because I usually hate the dreaded green apple, but this is more of a sweet red. Certainly interesting. This beer had a ton of hop character yet the bitterness is nearly non existent. Yeah yeah, another crappy review I shouldnt write, but this deserved a score.

Draft.  Pours a clear yellow orange with white head and nice lacing.  Smell slaps you up side the head.  Huge grapefruity citrus, resin and pine all packed in.  Taste is not quite a powerful and in your face, but really nice.  Really quite oily, almost like hop oil.  More grapefruit and resin and so easily drinkable and fresh feeling.  This certainly is one of those rare over 4 IPAs for me.  Just nasty good.

Bottle pours a clear bright amber with a nice soapy off white head that fades to a spotty film and shows minimal lacing. Aroma is awesome grapefruit and pine very resinous with a subtle caramel sweetness. Taste is just like above, but more of the caramel malt shows with a faint warming alcohol in the finish. Palate is sticky and full with a bitter chalky dry finish. This is a really nice brew, I hope this lingers around for a little bit cause I want to stock up on this stuff

12 oz bottle.  Crystal clear brass with a bumpy white head.  Nose is pine, polecat and grass with a hint of brown sugar.  Creamy body with hop juice and a numbing buzz.  Damn, this is some tasty stuff, must say im surprised.  Taste is tangerine, mandarins, citrus pith and pine.  Lingering caramel and grains, spicy rye; dry and sticky.

Pours a nice clear amber with a medium sized frothy head that dissipates after a minute and a half. Smells strongly of pine hops and citrus, particularly grapefruit and pineapple. Ale is 7.85%abv and well hid by a nice mixture of light hops and heavy malt. Beer taste mostly as it smells with malt has some caramel, Im not tasting brown sugar if Im supposed to. Finishes bitter, not try. Nice, well balanced, complex, all around ale.

Smells delicious. Better than poontang. Woody flowers in a cask. Come on flow wit me. This one is light golden but resinous in color. Use your imagination. If I may bastardize the words of my bartendress, "It tastes like every other Lagunitas beer ever made!" Either way I love it. And I pray, not hope, that you flowerhounds at Lagunitas fuck up more often.

Bottle pours a nice amber color with a thin white head.  The aroma is amazing with resinous hops taking the profile.  Taste is more IPA than American Strong with pine resin and some citrus notes.  Very well balanced, but quite bitter.  Body is medium to light and the beer is super well blended with all the malts.  A very good complement to the pungent hops.  Overall, I am pleasantly surprised by this one.  Love it.

Clear, pale golden with a decent size white frothy head.  Highly citrus aroma, a bit of pine, light caramel malt sweetness.  Medium body with decent carbonation.  Flavor is powerfully citrus hopped, tropical, fruit, light sweetness, and a hint of toasted malt.  Bitter finish.  Not at all what I expected.  Great beer.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2012 Clear golden, with a thick, lacing, off-white head. Aroma full of grapefruit and resin, rye, and a little sweet malt. Taste is malty and a little sweet, with a solid finishing bitterness. Medium bodied. Very good.

On draft at Brass Tap in Wesley Chapel.  Pours a clear gold with a white head.  Nose is malt, citrus, grapefruit, bits of pine, and spices along with hints of rye.  Flavor is similar- medium in body, bitter orange and kumquat with citrus all over the rye and caramel.  A hint of booze around, but all in all a nice, drinkable beer.

you know what, this is actually a good beer. its big, spicy, hoppy, malty, sweet and bitter, its tasty. pours very light, drinks very hoppy and light more like a iipa or something. theres a lot of tropical, soay and astringent hops in here, all very nice. drinks well, not sure how it will age, but it seems like a celebration type beer in the aging potential category.

Bottle from Whole Foods Market Charlottesville. Pours a clear amber color with a medium sized frothy white head. Fair head retention. Aroma of fruity hops with floral, citrus and tropical notes. The taste is bitter hops, berries, tropical notes, toasted grain and a resin finish. Medium bodied. Nice beer.

Bottle at Lush in Chicago. Pours amber gold with a white head. Floral and citrus aroma. Very pale malt backbone, and loaded with spicy and citrus hops. Dry finish, and slightly resiny. Very easy to drink. Perhaps a tad overattenuated for my tastes, as I think a little more residual sugars would make the hop flavors pop out.

I agree with most, this is more along the lines of an ipa than an American Strong Ale. Pours a clean, solid gold color. Just amazing how clear this beer is.  Strong fruity nose, some peaches, some pineapple. Very citric. Taste is almost the same, lemony-pineapple.  Medium body that youd think would be stickier that it is. Some of the alcohol comes through but very drinkable.  Such a great beer.

Bottle.  Light orange pour with one inch head that quickly recedes. Aroma of pineapple really jumps out at you.  Aroma also includes pine, sweet red grapefruit, and sugar.  Taste is brown sugary sweet with a little hop bite.  I can see why this is classified as an American Strong Ale, as the taste really is not that hoppy.  This was really good.  I want more.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2014 Clear golden/copper pour thin white head light lacing .... aroma is of pungent floral hops and resiny citrusy/piney hops .... taste is piney with sweet resiny citrusy hops pungent floral hops and bitter spicy rye with some light sweet malts on the backend .... finish is dry and bitter with a spicy kick that lingers for a while ... mouthfeel is of hop oils and lively from the spices, slick and oily .... ibus def well represented ... abv hidden well not a bad brew

Pretty much a double ipa. Big citrus, with bitter pine or peel notes; melon/peaches. Similar to a good Southern Tier 2xipa. Good lead in to Hopslam next month. Leaves a great resiny hue on the palate.

Bottle. It pours very clear yellow/gold with a small white head. The aroma is super pungent with pine, cat pee, dank, and tropical fruit. Love it. The flavor is more of the same with insane hop flavors balanced nicely with some sweet maltiness that does not distract from the hop character or gum up the body. In fact it is very light and drinkable considering the ABV. My only complaint is about the very confusing packaging. Nothing about this beer suggests "holiday" to me.

12 oz. bottle from SoHo Organic Market in Elizabeth City, NC.  Copper colored pour with an off-white head.  Floral and citrus hop aroma.  Juicy grapefruit flavor with tons of bitter pine and grassy hop flavor as well.  This is pretty much a DIPA even though the style on this site suggests otherwise.  A really nice substitute that I hope will become their standard holiday ale.

12oz pours golden yellow color with a quickly disappearing white head. the aroma is of citrusy/resiny hops and the fruit...yep i said fruit, mangos jumped out of the glass at me. the first taste was like an incredible experience. the flavor of the citrusy hops climbs all over your tongue and then slowly disappears into this fruity concoction of mangos, possibly peach or some other fleshy type fruit. there is no bitterness in the hops this beer just seems to slide down nicely and it very good. personally i am glad they messed up this year and made this beer. thanks guys.

Ask and ye shall receive I suppose. Just yesterday I was ruing not being able to try this.... I show up to my homebrew clubs Christmas party last night and lo and behold there were multiple bottles of this that had been brought.... Awesome.

Pours a perfectly clear golden color with a medium head that leaves some lacing on the glass.

The aroma is dank and just purely hoppy, herbal, citrusy, hoppy, hoppy, and hoppy. The beer is endlessly pungent and just a pleasure to stick your nose in front of, it is anything but complex but it doesnt need to be complex it smells great doing exactly what it does. 

The flavor follows the "simply hoppy" theme. Some resiny notes work well alongside the citrus and melon character of the beer & the beer displays that wonderful tongue wrenching bitterness without a note of astringency that is as much a physical sensation as it is a flavor. The beer is largely dry but gives a perception of sweetness from all the fruit forward hops. 

Welp, at least I got to try it.

How is this listed as an "American Strong Ale" when it is one of the clearest examples of a west Coast India Pale Ale Ive tried in ages? Poppycock!
Theres no way this isnt an ipa. Crazy citrus, powerful bitter taste, great beer to have on tap at Uber. Its honestly a little bit weaker version of Pliny the Elder. Super balanced, great beer.

Well for me this was just below Pliny the Elder that I got the chance to guzzle on tap in Estes Park. Didnt suck that they had Russian River Barrel-Aged Sours way below retail. ... Anyways. This was Mind-Blowingly good and nearly faultless. Huge apricot, mango, coconut, pinesol, lemongrass, basil and lemon oil. Its just a ridiculous beer out of the blue. Made me open a Rate Beer account.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2012 12 oz bottle.  I was sad to have missed this on tap, but Ill keep a lookout since Ive been a (relatively) good boy this year.  I was shocked by the light orange, almost pink-tinted pour.  I was still lightly under the impression this was going to somehow be a Christmas ale, of the traditional sort.  Nose is typical Lagunitas hoppy goodness, with a bit of the typical Lagunitas farmhouse funkiness.  The taste has the first burst of hoppiness, but a bunch of livliness and high fruit behind.  Bit of Hop Stoopid, bit more of Sumpin Sumpin, and a hint of the "wild".    I like it a bunch.  The more I drink it, the more I like it.  Its very similar to what  Iremember the first batches of Hop Stoopid being.
